title: Helianthus grosseserratus
text:
Helianthus grosseserratus, commonly known as sawtooth sunflower or thick-tooth sunflower, is a perennial <a href="Helianthus">sunflower</a> in the family Asteraceae, with a large flowering head (inflorescence).
The plant may reach 3–12 feet (91–366 cm) in height and is found along streams, damp prairies and roadsides in the eastern and central parts of Canada and the United States, primarily in the northern <a href="Great%20Plains">Great Plains</a> and <a href="Great%20Lakes%20Region">Great Lakes Region</a>, with additional populations as far as <a href="Maine">Maine</a>, <a href="Georgia%20%28U.S.%20state%29">Georgia</a>, and <a href="Texas">Texas</a>. It prefers full sun and moist, fertile loamy soil with high organic content.
The <a href="leaf%20shape">lanceolate</a> leaves are simple and alternate and may reach 4 to 12 inches (10–30 cm) long and from 1 to 4 inches (2–10 cm) wide. The leaves have large teeth along the edges (hence the name, "sawtooth") to occasionally nearly entire and the tips are pointed.
The <a href="Head%20%28botany%29">head</a> (formally composite flower) is 3 to 4 inches (7–10 cm) wide with golden-yellow disk flowers that bloom in summer and autumn. The 10-20 yellow ray florets are about 1.5 inches (3.81 cm) long. The fruit is a single <a href="achene">achene</a> within a husk.
Various insects, birds and mammals (including cattle) feed on either the plant or its seeds.
Native Americans used to treat burns with a poultice made from the flowers.
